The **thalamus** (from [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language")
[θάλαμος](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%B8%CE%AC%CE%BB%CE%B1%CE%BC%CE%BF%CF%82
"wikt:θάλαμος"), "chamber")[1] is the large mass of [gray
matter](/wiki/Gray_matter "Gray matter") in the dorsal part of the
diencephalon of the brain with several functions such as relaying of
[sensory](/wiki/Sensory_neuron "Sensory neuron") signals, including
[motor](/wiki/Motor_neuron "Motor neuron") signals, to the cerebral
cortex,[2][3][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing
sources")_] and the regulation of [consciousness](/wiki/Consciousness
"Consciousness"), [sleep](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep"), and
[alertness](/wiki/Alertness "Alertness")[4]

It is a [midline](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/midline "wikt:midline")
symmetrical structure of two halves, within the [vertebrate](/wiki/Vertebrate
"Vertebrate") [brain](/wiki/Brain "Brain"), situated between the [cerebral
cortex](/wiki/Cerebral_cortex "Cerebral cortex") and the
[midbrain](/wiki/Midbrain "Midbrain").

It is the main product of the [embryonic](/wiki/Embryo "Embryo")
[diencephalon](/wiki/Diencephalon "Diencephalon"), as first assigned by
[Wilhelm His, Sr.](/wiki/Wilhelm_His,_Sr. "Wilhelm His, Sr.") in 1893.[5]

## Anatomy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Anatomy")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/78/Thalamus_small.gif)](/wiki/File:Thalamus_small.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Thalamus_small.gif "Enlarge")

The thalamus in a 360° rotation

The thalamus is located in the [forebrain](/wiki/Forebrain "Forebrain") which
is superior to the midbrain, near the center of the brain, with nerve fibers
projecting out to the cerebral cortex in all directions. The medial surface of
the thalamus constitutes the upper part of the lateral wall of the [third
ventricle](/wiki/Third_ventricle "Third ventricle"), and is connected to the
corresponding surface of the opposite thalamus by a flattened gray band, the
[interthalamic adhesion](/wiki/Interthalamic_adhesion "Interthalamic
adhesion").

### Blood supply[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Blood supply")]

The thalamus derives its blood supply from a number of arteries: the polar
artery ([posterior communicating artery](/wiki/Posterior_communicating_artery
"Posterior communicating artery")), paramedian thalamic-subthalamic arteries,
inferolateral (thalamogeniculate) arteries, and [posterior (medial and
lateral) choroidal
arteries](/wiki/Posterior_cerebral_artery#Choroidal_branches "Posterior
cerebral artery").[6] These are all branches of the [posterior cerebral
artery](/wiki/Posterior_cerebral_artery "Posterior cerebral artery").[7]

Some people have the [artery of Percheron](/wiki/Artery_of_Percheron "Artery
of Percheron"), which is a rare anatomic variation in which a single arterial
trunk arises from the posterior cerebral artery to supply both parts of the
thalamus.

### Thalamic nuclei[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Thalamic nuclei")]

See also: [List of thalamic nuclei](/wiki/List_of_thalamic_nuclei "List of
thalamic nuclei")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Thalmus.png/220px-
Thalmus.png)](/wiki/File:Thalmus.png)

[](/wiki/File:Thalmus.png "Enlarge")

Nuclei of the thalamus

The thalamus is part of a nuclear complex structured of four parts, the
[hypothalamus](/wiki/Hypothalamus "Hypothalamus"),
[epithalamus](/wiki/Epithalamus "Epithalamus"),
[prethalamus](/wiki/Prethalamus "Prethalamus") (formerly called ventral
thalamus), and dorsal thalamus.[8][_[need quotation to
verify](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]

Derivatives of the [diencephalon](/wiki/Diencephalon "Diencephalon") also
include the dorsally-located [epithalamus](/wiki/Epithalamus "Epithalamus")
(essentially the [habenula](/wiki/Habenula "Habenula") and annexes) and the
perithalamus (prethalamus) containing the [zona incerta](/wiki/Zona_incerta
"Zona incerta") and the [thalamic reticular
nucleus](/wiki/Thalamic_reticular_nucleus "Thalamic reticular nucleus"). Due
to their different [ontogenetic](/wiki/Ontogenetic "Ontogenetic") origins, the
epithalamus and the perithalamus are formally distinguished from the thalamus
proper.

The thalamus comprises a system of [lamellae](/wiki/Lamella_\(anatomy\)
"Lamella \(anatomy\)") (made up of [myelinated](/wiki/Myelin "Myelin")
[fibers](/wiki/Axon "Axon")) separating different thalamic subparts. Other
areas are defined by distinct clusters of [neurons](/wiki/Neuron "Neuron"),
such as the [periventricular nucleus](/wiki/Periventricular_nucleus
"Periventricular nucleus"), the intralaminar elements, the "nucleus limitans",
and others.[9] These latter structures, different in structure from the major
part of the thalamus, have been grouped together into the
_[allothalamus](/wiki/Allothalamus "Allothalamus")_ as opposed to the
_[isothalamus](/wiki/Isothalamus "Isothalamus")_.[10] This distinction
simplifies the global description of the thalamus.

### Connections[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Connections")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Spinal_cord_tracts_-
_English.svg/220px-Spinal_cord_tracts_-
_English.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Spinal_cord_tracts_-_English.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Spinal_cord_tracts_-_English.svg "Enlarge")

The thalamus is connected to the spinal cord via the [spinothalamic
tract](/wiki/Spinothalamic_tract "Spinothalamic tract").

The thalamus is manifoldly connected to the hippocampus via the [mammillo-
thalamic tract](/wiki/Mammillothalamic_fasciculus "Mammillothalamic
fasciculus"), this tract comprises the [mammillary
bodies](/wiki/Mammillary_bodies "Mammillary bodies") and
[fornix](/wiki/Fornix_of_the_brain "Fornix of the brain").[11]

The thalamus is connected to the [cerebral cortex](/wiki/Cerebral_cortex
"Cerebral cortex") via the [thalamocortical
radiations](/wiki/Thalamocortical_radiations "Thalamocortical
radiations").[12]

The [spinothalamic tract](/wiki/Spinothalamic_tract "Spinothalamic tract") is
a sensory pathway originating in the spinal cord. It transmits information to
the thalamus about pain, temperature, itch and crude touch. There are two main
parts: the [lateral spinothalamic tract](/wiki/Lateral_spinothalamic_tract
"Lateral spinothalamic tract"), which transmits pain and temperature, and the
[anterior (or ventral) spinothalamic tract](/wiki/Anterior_spinothalamic_tract
"Anterior spinothalamic tract"), which transmits crude touch and pressure.

## Function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Function")]

The thalamus has multiple functions, generally believed to act as a relay
station, or [hub](/wiki/Hub_\(network_science\) "Hub \(network science\)"),
relaying information between different subcortical areas and the [cerebral
cortex](/wiki/Cerebral_cortex "Cerebral cortex").[13] In particular, every
sensory system (with the exception of the [olfactory
system](/wiki/Olfactory_system "Olfactory system")) includes a thalamic
nucleus that receives sensory signals and sends them to the associated primary
cortical area.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] For the visual system, for example, inputs from
the [retina](/wiki/Retina "Retina") are sent to the [lateral geniculate
nucleus](/wiki/Lateral_geniculate_nucleus "Lateral geniculate nucleus") of the
thalamus, which in turn projects to the [visual cortex](/wiki/Visual_cortex
"Visual cortex") in the [occipital lobe](/wiki/Occipital_lobe "Occipital
lobe").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] The thalamus is believed to both process sensory information as
well as relay it—each of the primary sensory relay areas receives strong
feedback connections from the cerebral cortex.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Similarly the [medial geniculate nucleus](/wiki/Medial_geniculate_nucleus
"Medial geniculate nucleus") acts as a key [auditory](/wiki/Auditory_system
"Auditory system") relay between the [inferior
colliculus](/wiki/Inferior_colliculus "Inferior colliculus") of the
[midbrain](/wiki/Midbrain "Midbrain") and the [primary auditory
cortex](/wiki/Primary_auditory_cortex "Primary auditory cortex").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
[ventral posterior nucleus](/wiki/Ventral_posterior_nucleus "Ventral posterior
nucleus") is a key [somatosensory](/wiki/Somatosensory "Somatosensory") relay,
which sends touch and [proprioceptive](/wiki/Proprioceptive "Proprioceptive")
information to the [primary somatosensory
cortex](/wiki/Primary_somatosensory_cortex "Primary somatosensory
cortex").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The thalamus also plays an important role in regulating states of [sleep and
wakefulness](/wiki/Neuroscience_of_sleep "Neuroscience of sleep").[14]
Thalamic nuclei have strong reciprocal connections with the cerebral cortex,
forming [thalamo-cortico-thalamic circuits](/wiki/Thalamo-cortico-
thalamic_circuits "Thalamo-cortico-thalamic circuits") that are believed to be
involved with [consciousness](/wiki/Consciousness "Consciousness").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
thalamus plays a major role in regulating arousal, the level of awareness, and
activity. Damage to the thalamus can lead to permanent [coma](/wiki/Coma
"Coma").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The role of the thalamus in the more anterior [pallidal](/wiki/Pallidal
"Pallidal") and [nigral](/wiki/Nigral "Nigral") territories in the [basal
ganglia](/wiki/Basal_ganglia "Basal ganglia") system disturbances is
recognized but still poorly understood. The contribution of the thalamus to
vestibular or to [tectal](/wiki/Tectal "Tectal") functions is almost ignored.
The thalamus has been thought of as a "relay" that simply forwards signals to
the cerebral cortex. Newer research suggests that thalamic function is more
selective.[15] Many different functions are linked to various regions of the
thalamus. This is the case for many of the sensory systems (except for the
olfactory system), such as the [auditory](/wiki/Auditory_system "Auditory
system"), [somatic](/wiki/Somatic_sensory_system "Somatic sensory system"),
[visceral](/wiki/Visceral "Visceral"), [gustatory](/wiki/Gustatory
"Gustatory") and [visual systems](/wiki/Visual_system "Visual system") where
localized lesions provoke specific sensory deficits. A major role of the
thalamus is support of motor and language systems, and much of the circuitry
implicated for these systems is shared. The thalamus is _functionally
connected_ to the [hippocampus](/wiki/Hippocampus "Hippocampus")[16] as part
of the extended hippocampal system at the thalamic anterior nuclei[17] with
respect to spatial memory and spatial sensory datum they are crucial for human
episodic memory and rodent event memory.[18][19] There is support for the
hypothesis that thalamic regions connection to particular parts of the mesio-
temporal lobe provide differentiation of the functioning of recollective and
familiarity memory.[11]

The neuronal information processes necessary for motor control were proposed
as a network involving the thalamus as a subcortical motor center.[20] Through
investigations of the anatomy of the brains of primates[21] the nature of the
interconnected tissues of the [cerebellum](/wiki/Cerebellum "Cerebellum") to
the multiple motor cortices suggested that the thalamus fulfills a key
function in providing the specific channels from the basal ganglia and
[cerebellum](/wiki/Cerebellum "Cerebellum") to the cortical motor
areas.[22][23] In an investigation of the saccade and antisaccade[24] motor
response in three monkeys, the thalamic regions were found to be involved in
the generation of antisaccade eye-movement.[25]

## Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Development")]

The thalamic complex is composed of the perithalamus (or prethalamus,
previously also known as ventral thalamus), the mid-diencephalic organiser
(which forms later the [zona limitans
intrathalamica](/wiki/Zona_limitans_intrathalamica "Zona limitans
intrathalamica") (ZLI) ) and the thalamus (dorsal thalamus).[26][27] The
development of the thalamus can be subdivided into three steps.[28] The
thalamus is the largest structure deriving from the embryonic
[diencephalon](/wiki/Diencephalon "Diencephalon"), the posterior part of the
forebrain situated between the midbrain and the cerebrum.

### Early brain
development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Early brain development")]

After [neurulation](/wiki/Neurulation "Neurulation") the anlage of the
[prethalamus](/wiki/Prethalamus "Prethalamus") and the thalamus is induced
within the neural tube. Data from different vertebrate model organisms support
a model in which the interaction between two [transcription
factors](/wiki/Transcription_factor "Transcription factor"), Fez and Otx, are
of decisive importance. Fez is expressed in the prethalamus, and functional
experiments show that Fez is required for prethalamus formation.[29][30]
Posteriorly, Otx1 and Otx2 abut the expression domain of Fez and are required
for proper development of the thalamus.[31][32]

### Formation of progenitor
domains[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Formation of progenitor domains")]

Early in thalamic development two progenitor domains form, a caudal domain
(TH-C) and a rostral domain (TH-R). The caudal domain gives rise to all of the
glutamatergic neurons in the adult thalamus while the rostral domain gives
rise to all of the GABAergic neurons in the adult thalamus.[33]

### The formation of the mid-diencephalic organiser
(MDO)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section:
The formation of the mid-diencephalic organiser \(MDO\)")]

At the interface between the expression domains of Fez and Otx, the mid-
diencephalic organizer (MDO, also called the ZLI organiser) is induced within
the thalamic [anlage](/wiki/Primordium "Primordium"). The MDO is the central
signalling organizer in the thalamus. A lack of the organizer leads to the
absence of the thalamus. The MDO matures from ventral to dorsal during
development. Members of the [SHH](/wiki/Sonic_hedgehog "Sonic hedgehog")
family and of the [Wnt](/wiki/Wnt_signaling_pathway "Wnt signaling pathway")
family are the main principal signals emitted by the MDO.

Besides its importance as signalling center, the organizer matures into the
morphological structure of the [zona limitans intrathalamica
(ZLI)](/wiki/Zona_limitans_intrathalamica "Zona limitans intrathalamica").

### Maturation and parcellation of the
thalamus[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Maturation and parcellation of the thalamus")]

After its induction, the MDO starts to orchestrate the development of the
thalamic anlage by release of signalling molecules such as
[SHH](/wiki/Sonic_hedgehog "Sonic hedgehog").[34] In mice, the function of
signaling at the MDO has not been addressed directly due to a complete absence
of the [diencephalon](/wiki/Diencephalon "Diencephalon") in SHH mutants.[35]

Studies in chicks have shown that SHH is both necessary and sufficient for
thalamic gene induction.[36] In [zebrafish](/wiki/Zebrafish "Zebrafish"), it
was shown that the expression of two SHH genes, SHH-a and SHH-b (formerly
described as twhh) mark the MDO territory, and that SHH signaling is
sufficient for the molecular differentiation of both the prethalamus and the
thalamus but is not required for their maintenance and SHH signaling from the
MDO/alar plate is sufficient for the maturation of prethalamic and thalamic
territory while ventral Shh signals are dispensable.[37]

The exposure to SHH leads to differentiation of thalamic neurons. SHH
signaling from the MDO induces a posterior-to-anterior wave of expression the
proneural gene [Neurogenin1](/wiki/Neurogenins "Neurogenins") in the major
(caudal) part of the thalamus, and Ascl1 (formerly Mash1) in the remaining
narrow stripe of rostral thalamic cells immediately adjacent to the MDO, and
in the prethalamus.[38][39]

This zonation of proneural gene expression leads to the differentiation of
glutamatergic relay neurons from the Neurogenin1+ precursors and of GABAergic
inhibitory neurons from the Ascl1+ precursors. In fish, selection of these
alternative neurotransmitter fates is controlled by the dynamic expression of
Her6 the homolog of [HES1](/wiki/HES1 "HES1"). Expression of this hairy-like
bHLH [transcription factor](/wiki/Transcription_factor "Transcription
factor"), which represses Neurogenin but is required for Ascl1, is
progressively lost from the caudal thalamus but maintained in the prethalamus
and in the stripe of rostral thalamic cells. In addition, studies on chick and
mice have shown that blocking the Shh pathway leads to absence of the rostral
thalamus and substantial decrease of the caudal thalamus. The rostral thalamus
will give rise to the reticular nucleus mainly whereby the caudal thalamus
will form the relay thalamus and will be further subdivided in the [thalamic
nuclei](/wiki/Thalamic_nuclei "Thalamic nuclei").[28]

In humans, a common genetic variation in the promotor region of the [serotonin
transporter](/wiki/Serotonin_transporter "Serotonin transporter") (the SERT-
long and -short allele: [5-HTTLPR](/wiki/5-HTTLPR "5-HTTLPR")) has been shown
to affect the development of several regions of the thalamus in adults. People
who inherit two short [alleles](/wiki/Allele "Allele") (SERT-ss) have more
neurons and a larger volume in the [pulvinar](/wiki/Pulvinar_nucleus "Pulvinar
nucleus") and possibly the limbic regions of the thalamus. Enlargement of the
thalamus provides an anatomical basis for why people who inherit two SERT-ss
alleles are more vulnerable to [major
depression](/wiki/Major_depressive_disorder "Major depressive disorder"),
[posttraumatic stress disorder](/wiki/Posttraumatic_stress_disorder
"Posttraumatic stress disorder"), and suicide.[40]

## Clinical
significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thalamus&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Clinical significance")]

A cerebrovascular accident ([stroke](/wiki/Stroke "Stroke")) can lead to the
[thalamic syndrome](/wiki/Thalamic_syndrome "Thalamic syndrome"),[41] which
involves a one-sided burning or aching sensation often accompanied by [mood
swings](/wiki/Mood_disorder "Mood disorder"). Bilateral
[ischemia](/wiki/Ischemia "Ischemia") of the area supplied by the paramedian
artery can cause serious problems including [akinetic
mutism](/wiki/Akinetic_mutism "Akinetic mutism"), and be accompanied by
[oculomotor](/wiki/Oculomotor "Oculomotor") problems. A related concept is
[thalamocortical dysrhythmia](/wiki/Thalamocortical_dysrhythmia
"Thalamocortical dysrhythmia"). The occlusion of the [artery of
Percheron](/wiki/Artery_of_Percheron "Artery of Percheron") can lead to a
bilateral thalamus infarction.

[Korsakoff's syndrome](/wiki/Korsakoff%27s_syndrome "Korsakoff's syndrome")
stems from damage to the [mammillary body](/wiki/Mammillary_body "Mammillary
body"), the [mammillothalamic fasciculus](/wiki/Mammillothalamic_fasciculus
"Mammillothalamic fasciculus") or the thalamus.

[Fatal familial insomnia](/wiki/Fatal_familial_insomnia "Fatal familial
insomnia") is a hereditary [prion](/wiki/Prion "Prion") disease in which
degeneration of the thalamus occurs, causing the patient to gradually lose his
ability to sleep and progressing to a state of total [insomnia](/wiki/Insomnia
"Insomnia"), which invariably leads to death. In contrast, damage to the
thalamus can result in [coma](/wiki/Coma "Coma").

[Brain](/wiki/Human_brain "Human brain") and [spinal cord](/wiki/Spinal_cord
"Spinal cord"): [neural tracts](/wiki/Neural_pathway "Neural pathway") and
[fasciculi](/wiki/Nerve_fascicle "Nerve fascicle")  
---  
Sensory/  
ascending |  | [PCML](/wiki/Posterior_column-medial_lemniscus_pathway "Posterior column-medial lemniscus pathway") |  | [1°](/wiki/Posterior_column-medial_lemniscus_pathway#First_neuron "Posterior column-medial lemniscus pathway"): | 

  * [Pacinian corpuscle](/wiki/Lamellar_corpuscle "Lamellar corpuscle")/[Meissner's corpuscle](/wiki/Tactile_corpuscle "Tactile corpuscle") → **[Posterior column](/wiki/Posterior_column "Posterior column")** ([Gracile fasciculus](/wiki/Gracile_fasciculus "Gracile fasciculus")/[Cuneate fasciculus](/wiki/Cuneate_fasciculus "Cuneate fasciculus")) → [Gracile nucleus](/wiki/Gracile_nucleus "Gracile nucleus")/[Cuneate nucleus](/wiki/Cuneate_nucleus "Cuneate nucleus")

  
---|---  
[2°](/wiki/Posterior_column-medial_lemniscus_pathway#Second_neuron "Posterior column-medial lemniscus pathway"): | 

  * → _[sensory decussation](/wiki/Sensory_decussation "Sensory decussation")/arcuate fibers_ ([Posterior external arcuate fibers](/wiki/Posterior_external_arcuate_fibers "Posterior external arcuate fibers"), [Internal arcuate fibers](/wiki/Internal_arcuate_fibers "Internal arcuate fibers")) → [Medial lemniscus](/wiki/Medial_lemniscus "Medial lemniscus")/[Trigeminal lemniscus](/wiki/Trigeminal_lemniscus "Trigeminal lemniscus") → Thalamus ([VPL](/wiki/Ventral_posterolateral_nucleus "Ventral posterolateral nucleus"), [VPM](/wiki/Ventral_posteromedial_nucleus "Ventral posteromedial nucleus"))

  
[3°](/wiki/Posterior_column-medial_lemniscus_pathway#Third_neuron "Posterior column-medial lemniscus pathway"): | 

  * → [Posterior limb of internal capsule](/wiki/Posterior_limb_of_internal_capsule "Posterior limb of internal capsule") → [Postcentral gyrus](/wiki/Postcentral_gyrus "Postcentral gyrus")

  
[Anterolateral](/wiki/Anterolateral_system "Anterolateral system")/  
[pain](/wiki/Pain "Pain") |  | [Fast](/wiki/Nociception#Neospinothalamic_tract "Nociception")/lateral | 

  * 1° ([Free nerve ending](/wiki/Free_nerve_ending "Free nerve ending") → [A delta fiber](/wiki/A_delta_fiber "A delta fiber")) → 2° ([Anterior white commissure](/wiki/Anterior_white_commissure "Anterior white commissure") → **[Lateral](/wiki/Lateral_spinothalamic_tract "Lateral spinothalamic tract") and [Anterior](/wiki/Anterior_spinothalamic_tract "Anterior spinothalamic tract") [Spinothalamic tract](/wiki/Spinothalamic_tract "Spinothalamic tract")** → [Spinal lemniscus](/wiki/Spinothalamic_tract "Spinothalamic tract") → [VPL](/wiki/Ventral_posterolateral_nucleus "Ventral posterolateral nucleus") of Thalamus) → 3° ([Postcentral gyrus](/wiki/Postcentral_gyrus "Postcentral gyrus")) → 4° ([Posterior parietal cortex](/wiki/Posterior_parietal_cortex "Posterior parietal cortex"))

2° (**[Spinomesencephalic tract](/wiki/Spinomesencephalic_tract
"Spinomesencephalic tract")** → [Superior
colliculus](/wiki/Superior_colliculus "Superior colliculus") of [Midbrain
tectum](/wiki/Midbrain_tectum "Midbrain tectum"))  
---|---  
[Slow](/wiki/Nociception#Paleospinothalamic_tract "Nociception")/medial | 

  * 1° ([Group C nerve fiber](/wiki/Group_C_nerve_fiber "Group C nerve fiber") → **[Spinoreticular tract](/wiki/Spinoreticular_tract "Spinoreticular tract")** → [Reticular formation](/wiki/Reticular_formation "Reticular formation")) → 2° ([MD](/wiki/Medial_dorsal_nucleus "Medial dorsal nucleus") of Thalamus) → 3° ([Cingulate cortex](/wiki/Cingulate_cortex "Cingulate cortex"))

  
Motor/  
descending |  | Pyramidal | 

  * _flexion:_ [Primary motor cortex](/wiki/Primary_motor_cortex "Primary motor cortex") → [Posterior limb of internal capsule](/wiki/Posterior_limb_of_internal_capsule "Posterior limb of internal capsule") → [Decussation of pyramids](/wiki/Decussation_of_pyramids "Decussation of pyramids") → **[Corticospinal tract](/wiki/Pyramidal_tracts "Pyramidal tracts") ([Lateral](/wiki/Lateral_corticospinal_tract "Lateral corticospinal tract"), [Anterior](/wiki/Anterior_corticospinal_tract "Anterior corticospinal tract"))** → [Neuromuscular junction](/wiki/Neuromuscular_junction "Neuromuscular junction")

  
---|---  
[Extrapyramidal](/wiki/Extrapyramidal_system "Extrapyramidal system") |  | _flexion:_ | 

  * [Primary motor cortex](/wiki/Primary_motor_cortex "Primary motor cortex") → [Genu of internal capsule](/wiki/Genu_of_internal_capsule "Genu of internal capsule") → **[Corticobulbar tract](/wiki/Corticobulbar_tract "Corticobulbar tract")** → [Facial motor nucleus](/wiki/Facial_motor_nucleus "Facial motor nucleus") → [Facial muscles](/wiki/Facial_muscles "Facial muscles")

  
---|---  
_flexion:_ | 

  * [Red nucleus](/wiki/Red_nucleus "Red nucleus") → **[Rubrospinal tract](/wiki/Rubrospinal_tract "Rubrospinal tract")**

  
_extension:_ | 

  * [Vestibulocerebellum](/wiki/Anatomy_of_the_cerebellum#Phylogenetic_and_functional_divisions "Anatomy of the cerebellum") → [Vestibular nuclei](/wiki/Vestibular_nuclei "Vestibular nuclei") → **[Vestibulospinal tract](/wiki/Vestibulospinal_tract "Vestibulospinal tract")**

  
_extension:_ | 

  * [Vestibulocerebellum](/wiki/Anatomy_of_the_cerebellum#Phylogenetic_and_functional_divisions "Anatomy of the cerebellum") → [Reticular formation](/wiki/Reticular_formation "Reticular formation") → **[Reticulospinal tract](/wiki/Reticular_formation#Descending_reticulospinal_tracts "Reticular formation")**

  
  
  * [Midbrain tectum](/wiki/Midbrain_tectum "Midbrain tectum") → **[Tectospinal tract](/wiki/Tectospinal_tract "Tectospinal tract")** → muscles of neck

  
[Basal ganglia](/wiki/Basal_ganglia "Basal ganglia") |  | [_direct:_](/wiki/Direct_pathway_of_movement "Direct pathway of movement") |  1° ([Motor cortex](/wiki/Motor_cortex "Motor cortex") → [Striatum](/wiki/Striatum "Striatum")) → 2° ([GPi](/wiki/Medial_globus_pallidus "Medial globus pallidus")) → 3° ([Lenticular fasciculus](/wiki/Lenticular_fasciculus "Lenticular fasciculus")/[Ansa lenticularis](/wiki/Ansa_lenticularis "Ansa lenticularis") → [Thalamic fasciculus](/wiki/Thalamic_fasciculus "Thalamic fasciculus") → [VL](/wiki/Ventral_lateral_nucleus "Ventral lateral nucleus") of Thalamus) → 4° ([Thalamocortical radiations](/wiki/Thalamocortical_radiations "Thalamocortical radiations") → [Supplementary motor area](/wiki/Supplementary_motor_area "Supplementary motor area")) → 5° ([Motor cortex](/wiki/Motor_cortex "Motor cortex"))  
---|---  
[_indirect:_](/wiki/Indirect_pathway_of_movement "Indirect pathway of movement") |  1° ([Motor cortex](/wiki/Motor_cortex "Motor cortex") → [Striatum](/wiki/Striatum "Striatum")) → 2° ([GPe](/wiki/Lateral_globus_pallidus "Lateral globus pallidus")) → 3° ([Subthalamic fasciculus](/wiki/Subthalamic_fasciculus "Subthalamic fasciculus") → [Subthalamic nucleus](/wiki/Subthalamic_nucleus "Subthalamic nucleus")) → 4° ([Subthalamic fasciculus](/wiki/Subthalamic_fasciculus "Subthalamic fasciculus") → [GPi](/wiki/Medial_globus_pallidus "Medial globus pallidus")) → 5° ([Lenticular fasciculus](/wiki/Lenticular_fasciculus "Lenticular fasciculus")/[Ansa lenticularis](/wiki/Ansa_lenticularis "Ansa lenticularis") → [Thalamic fasciculus](/wiki/Thalamic_fasciculus "Thalamic fasciculus") → [VL](/wiki/Ventral_lateral_nucleus "Ventral lateral nucleus") of Thalamus) → 6° ([Thalamocortical radiations](/wiki/Thalamocortical_radiations "Thalamocortical radiations") → [Supplementary motor area](/wiki/Supplementary_motor_area "Supplementary motor area")) → 7° ([Motor cortex](/wiki/Motor_cortex "Motor cortex"))  
_[nigrostriatal pathway](/wiki/Nigrostriatal_pathway "Nigrostriatal pathway"):_ | 

  * [Pars compacta](/wiki/Substantia_nigra_pars_compacta "Substantia nigra pars compacta") → [Striatum](/wiki/Striatum "Striatum")

  
[Cerebellar](/wiki/Cerebellum "Cerebellum") |  | Afferent | 

  * [Vestibular nuclei](/wiki/Vestibular_nuclei "Vestibular nuclei") → **[Vestibulocerebellar tract](/wiki/Vestibulocerebellar_tract "Vestibulocerebellar tract")** → [ICP](/wiki/Inferior_cerebellar_peduncle "Inferior cerebellar peduncle") → [Cerebellum](/wiki/Cerebellum "Cerebellum") → [Granule cell](/wiki/Cerebellum_granule_cell "Cerebellum granule cell")

  * [Pontine nuclei](/wiki/Pontine_nuclei "Pontine nuclei") → **[Pontocerebellar fibers](/wiki/Pontocerebellar_fibers "Pontocerebellar fibers")** → [MCP](/wiki/Middle_cerebellar_peduncle "Middle cerebellar peduncle") → [Deep cerebellar nuclei](/wiki/Deep_cerebellar_nuclei "Deep cerebellar nuclei") → [Granule cell](/wiki/Cerebellum_granule_cell "Cerebellum granule cell")

  * [Inferior olivary nucleus](/wiki/Inferior_olivary_nucleus "Inferior olivary nucleus") → **[Olivocerebellar tract](/wiki/Olivocerebellar_tract "Olivocerebellar tract")** → [ICP](/wiki/Inferior_cerebellar_peduncle "Inferior cerebellar peduncle") → [Hemisphere](/wiki/Cerebellar_hemisphere "Cerebellar hemisphere") → [Purkinje cell](/wiki/Purkinje_cell "Purkinje cell") → [Deep cerebellar nuclei](/wiki/Deep_cerebellar_nuclei "Deep cerebellar nuclei")

  
---|---  
Efferent | 

  * [Dentate nucleus](/wiki/Dentate_nucleus "Dentate nucleus") in [Lateral hemisphere/pontocerebellum](/wiki/Cerebellar_hemisphere "Cerebellar hemisphere") → [SCP](/wiki/Superior_cerebellar_peduncle "Superior cerebellar peduncle") → **[Dentatothalamic tract](/wiki/Dentatothalamic_tract "Dentatothalamic tract")** → Thalamus ([VL](/wiki/Ventral_lateral_nucleus "Ventral lateral nucleus")) → [Motor cortex](/wiki/Motor_cortex "Motor cortex")

  * [Interposed nucleus](/wiki/Interposed_nucleus "Interposed nucleus") in [Intermediate hemisphere/spinocerebellum](/wiki/Cerebellar_hemisphere "Cerebellar hemisphere") → [SCP](/wiki/Superior_cerebellar_peduncle "Superior cerebellar peduncle") → [Reticular formation](/wiki/Reticular_formation "Reticular formation"), or → **[Cerebellothalamic tract](/wiki/Cerebellothalamic_tract "Cerebellothalamic tract")** → [Red nucleus](/wiki/Red_nucleus "Red nucleus") → Thalamus ([VL](/wiki/Ventral_lateral_nucleus "Ventral lateral nucleus")) → [Motor cortex](/wiki/Motor_cortex "Motor cortex")

  * [Fastigial nucleus](/wiki/Fastigial_nucleus "Fastigial nucleus") in [Flocculonodular lobe/vestibulocerebellum](/wiki/Flocculonodular_lobe "Flocculonodular lobe") → **[Vestibulocerebellar tract](/wiki/Vestibulocerebellar_tract "Vestibulocerebellar tract")** → [Vestibular nuclei](/wiki/Vestibular_nuclei "Vestibular nuclei")

  
Bidirectional:  
[Spinocerebellar](/wiki/Spinocerebellar_tract "Spinocerebellar tract") |  | [Unconscious  
proprioception](/wiki/Proprioception#Conscious_and_unconscious_proprioception "Proprioception") | 

  * [lower limb](/wiki/Lower_limb "Lower limb") → 1° ([muscle spindles](/wiki/Muscle_spindle "Muscle spindle") → [DRG](/wiki/Dorsal_root_ganglion "Dorsal root ganglion")) → 2° ([Posterior thoracic nucleus](/wiki/Posterior_thoracic_nucleus "Posterior thoracic nucleus") → **[Dorsal/posterior spinocerebellar tract](/wiki/Dorsal_spinocerebellar_tract "Dorsal spinocerebellar tract")** → [ICP](/wiki/Inferior_cerebellar_peduncle "Inferior cerebellar peduncle") → [Cerebellar vermis](/wiki/Cerebellar_vermis "Cerebellar vermis"))

  * [upper limb](/wiki/Upper_limb "Upper limb") → 1° ([muscle spindles](/wiki/Muscle_spindle "Muscle spindle") → [DRG](/wiki/Dorsal_root_ganglion "Dorsal root ganglion")) → 2° ([Accessory cuneate nucleus](/wiki/Accessory_cuneate_nucleus "Accessory cuneate nucleus") → **[Cuneocerebellar tract](/wiki/Posterior_external_arcuate_fibers "Posterior external arcuate fibers")** → [ICP](/wiki/Inferior_cerebellar_peduncle "Inferior cerebellar peduncle") → [Anterior lobe of cerebellum](/wiki/Anterior_lobe_of_cerebellum "Anterior lobe of cerebellum"))

  
---|---  
[Reflex arc](/wiki/Reflex_arc "Reflex arc") | 

  * [lower limb](/wiki/Lower_limb "Lower limb") → 1° ([Golgi tendon organ](/wiki/Golgi_tendon_organ "Golgi tendon organ")) → 2° (**[Ventral/anterior spinocerebellar tract](/wiki/Ventral_spinocerebellar_tract "Ventral spinocerebellar tract")** → [SCP](/wiki/Superior_cerebellar_peduncle "Superior cerebellar peduncle") → [Cerebellar vermis](/wiki/Cerebellar_vermis "Cerebellar vermis"))

  * [upper limb](/wiki/Upper_limb "Upper limb") → 1° ([Golgi tendon organ](/wiki/Golgi_tendon_organ "Golgi tendon organ")) → 2° (**[Rostral spinocerebellar tract](/wiki/Rostral_spinocerebellar_tract "Rostral spinocerebellar tract")** → [ICP](/wiki/Inferior_cerebellar_peduncle "Inferior cerebellar peduncle") → [Cerebellum](/wiki/Cerebellum "Cerebellum"))
